L1.brief_rationale: The most fundamental topic in philosophy of mind; universally recognized even by non-specialists.
Central philosophical problem familiar to the general public through everyday moral and legal discourse.
The defining problem of the field; its name alone conveys the core tension between mental and physical.
Pre-theoretic concept shared across cultures and religions; universally known as referring to a non-physical self.
Everyday mental phenomenon studied philosophically; its nature and role in rationality are widely debated.
Basic mental process everyone experiences; raises foundational questions about how the mind represents the world.
Core mental faculty central to personal identity debates; universally understood at the lay level.
Foundational propositional attitude in folk psychology; discussed in everyday and philosophical contexts alike.
Basic motivational mental state; essential to action theory and folk psychological explanation.
The generic term for mental cognition; universally understood and philosophically foundational.
Widely experienced altered conscious state that raises questions about reality, hallucination, and the mind.
Publicly prominent topic whose philosophical dimension (can machines think?) is broadly recognized.
Questions about what makes a person the same over time are intuitive and culturally pervasive.

L2.brief_rationale: The view that mind and body are distinct substances; the first philosophical position students encounter in this field.
The dominant modern view that mental states are ultimately physical; a standard term in undergraduate philosophy.
The subjective, felt qualities of experience; introduced early in any philosophy of mind course.
Influential theory that mental states are defined by their causal roles; core undergraduate content.
The about-ness or directedness of mental states; a key concept taught in introductory courses.
The philosophical and psychological view that mental states reduce to behavioral dispositions; historically foundational.
The mind-brain identity theory identifying mental state types with brain state types; standard L2 content.
The radical view that folk psychological categories will be eliminated by mature neuroscience; widely taught.
The everyday framework of beliefs, desires, and intentions used to explain behavior; central to philosophy of mind debates.
The problem of how mental states cause physical events; a key puzzle for any non-eliminativist position.
A thought experiment arguing that physical duplicates without consciousness are conceivable; widely discussed.
What it is like to have an experience; the central target of debates about qualia and the hard problem.
The logical form of mental states like belief and desire; introduced in introductory philosophy of language and mind.

L3.brief_rationale: Chalmers's distinction between explaining cognitive functions and explaining subjective experience; requires working familiarity with debates.
Searle's argument that syntactic symbol manipulation cannot yield genuine understanding; students must grasp its mechanics to evaluate it.
The claim that the same mental state can be realized by different physical substrates; key objection to type identity theory.
The dependency relation where mental properties cannot vary without physical variation; requires careful understanding to apply correctly.
The view that each mental event token is identical to some physical event token; a more nuanced position than type identity theory.
The view that consciousness requires a mental state to be represented by a higher-order mental state; requires knowledge of the debate landscape.
Clark and Chalmers's argument that cognitive processes can extend into the environment; working knowledge requires understanding the parity principle.
The view that phenomenal properties reduce to representational content; a substantive theoretical commitment requiring field knowledge.
Putnam and Burge's view that mental content is partly determined by environment; requires understanding twin-earth thought experiments.
The view that mental events are causally inert byproducts of physical processes; students must understand why it is problematic.
Baars's cognitive architecture in which conscious contents are broadcast globally to many brain systems; bridges philosophy and cognitive science.
Tononi's mathematical framework identifying consciousness with integrated information (phi); requires working knowledge to distinguish from competitors.

L4.brief_rationale: Davidson's position that mental events are physical but mental descriptions cannot be reduced to physical laws; expert-level metaphysics of mind.
The thesis that intentionality is grounded in or identical to phenomenal consciousness; a technical debate among specialists.
Varela, Thompson, and Rosch's view that cognition is constituted through embodied action rather than internal representation; requires deep familiarity with 4E cognition debates.
The view that veridical perception and hallucination are fundamentally different in nature rather than sharing a common factor; a specialist debate in philosophy of perception.
Parfit's neo-Lockean account of personal identity via overlapping chains of psychological connections; requires detailed engagement with thought experiments.
Mental content determined solely by internal physical states, independent of environment; a technical response to content externalism.
The claim that perceptual states have representational content that does not require possession of concepts; a nuanced debate in epistemology and philosophy of mind.
Frankish's view that phenomenal consciousness as commonly conceived is an introspective illusion; a recent and technically demanding revisionary position.
Application of Frege's sense/reference distinction to mental representation and the problem of cognitive significance; requires expertise in philosophy of language and mind.
Lycan's variant holding that consciousness is inner perception by a dedicated monitoring system; distinguished from higher-order thought theories at expert level.
Clark and Friston's framework in which the brain is a hierarchical prediction machine; requires deep knowledge to understand its implications for consciousness and action.
Block's distinction between information being globally available for reasoning/report versus there being something it is like; a precise technical distinction essential to advanced debates.
